Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Multiscale Models for ABC Transporter Molecular Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the dynamics of biomolecules at the cell surface, including how molecules move across the cell membrane, is crucial to the basic understanding of life processes. The cell membrane normally acts as a barrier that selectively limits what enters the cell. This project explores the mechanisms by which transporters, or large proteins that reside in the cell membrane, actively export substances across the cell membrane. Multiscale simulations are developed to predict molecular behavior of these transporters. The project provides undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups in rural Maine with training in the scientific method, computational analysis, and molecular science--approaches vital to further advances in knowledge and society. A weeklong summer workshop has been established to introduce Maine students to Unix programming and protein modeling. Student researchers are involved in carrying out all aspects of the research and receive advanced training in the theoretical foundations of statistical thermodynamics. Returning students acquire teaching experience by co-facilitating summer workshops, interactive biochemistry classes, and molecular visualization labs.

Experimental collaborators trapped the E. coli ABC transporter, MsbA, in distinct states of its conformational cycle, including open and closed inward-facing conformers and an outward-facing post-hydrolysis conformation. Paramagnetic spin label measurements subsequently confirmed the ATP-dependent alternating accessibility of the transmembrane protein chamber to the intra- and extracellular bilayer leaflets. This project connects these existing structural data with a functional picture of the dynamic molecular interactions that accompany protein conformational cycling and couple ATP hydrolysis to substrate translocation. Consistent with the Integrating Across Scales priority of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, a multiscale description is developed from atomistic simulations to simulate the dynamics of a large molecular machine residing in its lipid bilayer environment. The role of annular phospholipid solvation on translocation of the flippase's lipid substrate is specifically explored. The force field lipid and protein parameter set created by the project is not limited to transporters and is of general utility for simulations of membrane protein systems, their diffusive dynamics, and molecular interactions. Undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups are incorporated and trained in the foundations of computational science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has only recently become appreciated that the function of membrane proteins at the cell surface is sensitive to structural interactions with adjacent phospholipids contained in the lipid bilayer membrane. Computational research was performed to investigate the molecular level interactions controlling the function of two ABC transport proteins, MsbA and P-glycoprotein. MsbA transports lipopolysaccharide, an essential component of the outer bacterial membrane in gram-negative bacteria, while P-glycoprotein is responsible for exporting drugs and toxins out of human cells. Both proteins rely on the energy obtained from hydrolysis of an ATP molecule to cause a conformational change in the transmembrane helices, whose binding chamber adopts an outward facing orientation to mediate cellular efflux of substrates.

A multiscale simulation package was developed in-house and shared with the scientific community. Known as CgProt, the force field is capable of performing molecular dynamics simulations of any protein of known structure in the context of physiologically representative membranes consisting of common neutral or negatively-charged phospholipids and cholesterol. By developing model parameters at a coarse-grained--less than atomistic--resolution, larger biologically relevant membrane systems were studied at longer timescales than can be obtained with conventional force field simulations. The protein model was calibrated using experimental data to capture the thermodynamics of insertion into the nonpolar bilayer interior. Aqueous salt ions were parameterized and added to the membrane-protein simulation systems in order to properly capture electrostatic interactions and stabilize proteins inserted in the membrane. Microsecond CgProt simulations were found to be successful in exploring conformational changes associated with the alternating access functional transport mechanism of MsbA and P-glycoprotein.

The two transporters contain a larger amphiphilic transmembrane chamber capable of polyspecific binding to translocate a variety of chemical substrates. Long timescale simulations of molecular diffusion within mixed lipid bilayers revealed the presence of weak but persistent lipid-protein binding interactions. Both the interior and exterior of the transmembrane transport chamber were bound by a shell of transient nonpolar phospholipid tails, known as annular lipids. Moreover, zwitterionic and negative phospholipid head groups were observed to participate in charge-charge interactions with basic and acidic protein sidechains on the protein surface. The locations of charge interactions within the transmembrane chamber during its conformational cycle reveal a translocation pathway by which lipid substrates can be flipped from inside to outside the cell membrane, providing a rationale for the seemingly unrelated substrates that can be transported.

The research project has provided a diverse body of undergraduate students and junior researchers with mentoring and training in the scientific method, computational analysis, and molecular science--approaches vital to further advances in knowledge and society. The research has directly impacted other laboratories in the scientific community, who have utilized the CgProt force field in their own research. Lastly, laboratory-trained students acquired teaching experience and furthered their professional development by serving as Supplemental Instruction leaders, developing curricular materials, and assisting in an annual weeklong computer modeling workshop held for the local community. With this background, several of the student researchers have gone on to pursue careers in science, technology, and research.
